Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the significance of the abhaya mudra gesture? Options: A. It represents the power of the material world., B. It represents the importance of spiritual growth., C. It represents safety and assurance., D. It represents the cycle of life. Correct Option: C
Question 7: In which sacred city is Annapurna said to have first appeared? Options: A. Kashi, B. Varanasi, C. Benares, D. Ayodhya Correct Option: A
Question 8: How does Lord Shiva approach Annapurna in the story? Options: A. He approaches her as a powerful deity., B. He approaches her as a humble beggar., C. He approaches her as a proud warrior., D. He approaches her as a wise sage. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the golden bowl and the jewel-encrusted ladle in the story? Options: A. They represent the power of the material world., B. They represent the importance of spiritual growth., C. They represent the provision of food and sustenance., D. They represent the cycle of life. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the overall message of the story? Options: A. The material world is an illusion., B. The material world is a cycle of life that must be sustained., C. The spiritual world is more important than the material world., D. The world is a place of suffering and hardship. Correct Option: B

and rumbling bellies, to the equilibrium of the Earth.

slayer of demons, protector, and omniscient observer 
of the universe— was testing his wife’s patience. Historically, the union between 
Shiva and Parvati was a glorious one. They maintained the equilibrium 
between thought and action on which the well-being 
of the world depended. Without Parvati as the agent of energy, 
growth, and transformation on Earth, Shiva would become a detached observer, 
and the world would remain static. But together, the two formed 
a divine union known as Ardhanarishvara–– a sacred combination which brought fertility and connection 
to all living things. For these reasons, Parvati was worshipped
far and wide as the mother of the natural world–– and the essential counterpart 
to Shiva’s powers of raw creation. She oversaw humanity’s material comforts; and ensured that the Earth’s inhabitants
were bonded to each other physically, emotionally, and spiritually. Yet a rift had grown 
between these two formidable forces. While Parvati sustained daily life 
with care and control, Shiva had begun to belittle 
his wife’s essential work— and insisted on quarreling 
about their roles in the universe. He believed that Brahma, 
the Creator of the world, had conceived the material plane 
purely for his own fancy. And therefore, all material things 
were merely distractions called māyā— nothing but a cosmic illusion. For millennia Parvati 
had merely smiled knowingly as Shiva dismissed

the importance of her work once and for all. She took flight from the world, withdrawing her half of the cosmic energy

and armed with a jewel-encrusted ladle. As word of this hopeful figure spread, she was worshipped as Annapurna,

in the sacred city of Kashi, or the Place of Freedom,

to fill the bellies of the people until they could eat no more. But it was not only mere mortals

blooming all around him, Lord Shiva himself approached the goddess
with an empty bowl and begged for food and forgiveness. For this reason, the supreme deity

while the right forms the abhaya mudra–– a gesture of safety and assurance. With these symbols, 
this powerful avatar makes it clear that the material world 
is anything but an illusion. Rather, it is a cycle of life 
that must be sustained— from the feeding of open mouths 
and rumbling bellies, to the equilibrium of the Earth.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 132 CE, Chinese polymath Zhang Heng presented the Han court with 
his latest invention. This large vase, he claimed, could tell them whenever an earthquake 
occurred in their kingdom– including the direction 
they should send aid. The court was somewhat skeptical, especially when the device triggered 
on a seemingly quiet afternoon. But when messengers came 
for help days later, their doubts turned to gratitude. Today, we no longer rely on pots to 
identify seismic events, but earthquakes still offer a unique
challenge to those trying to track them. So why are earthquakes so 
hard to anticipate, and how could we get better 
at predicting them? To answer that, we need to understand some theories 
behind how earthquakes occur. Earth’s crust is made from several vast, 
jagged slabs of rock called tectonic plates, each riding on a hot, partially molten
layer of Earth’s mantle. This causes the plates to 
spread very slowly, at anywhere from 1 to 20 
centimeters per year. But these tiny movements are powerful 
enough to cause deep cracks in the
interacting plates. And in unstable zones, the intensifying pressure may 
ultimately trigger an earthquake. It’s hard enough to monitor these 
miniscule movements, but the factors that turn shifts into 
seismic events are far more varied. Different fault lines juxtapose 
different rocks– some of which are stronger–or weaker–
under pressure. Diverse rocks also react differently to
friction and high temperatures. Some partially melt, and can release
lubricating fluids made of superheated minerals that reduce fault line friction. But some are left dry, prone to dangerous build-ups of pressure. And all these faults are subject to 
varying gravitational forces, as well as the currents of hot rocks
moving throughout Earth’s mantle. So which of these hidden variables 
should we be analyzing, and how do they fit into our 
growing prediction toolkit? Because some of these forces occur 
at largely constant rates, the behavior of the plates 
is somewhat cyclical. Today, many of our most reliable clues 
come from long-term forecasting, related to when and where earthquakes 
have previously occurred. At the scale of millennia, this allows us to make predictions 
about when highly active faults, like the San Andreas, are overdue for a massive earthquake. But due to the many variables involved, this method can only predict 
very loose timeframes. To predict more imminent events, researchers have investigated the 
vibrations Earth elicits before a quake. Geologists have long used seismometers to track and map these tiny shifts
in the earth’s crust. And today, most smartphones are 
also capable of recording primary seismic waves. With a network of phones around the globe, scientists could potentially 
crowdsource a rich, detailed warning system that alerts 
people to incoming quakes. Unfortunately, phones might not be able
to provide the advance notice needed to enact safety protocols. But such detailed readings 
would still be useful for prediction tools like NASA’s 
Quakesim software, which can use a rigorous blend of 
geological data to identify regions at risk. However, recent studies indicate the most telling signs of a quake might be
invisible to all these sensors. In 2011, just before an earthquake struck 
the east coast of Japan, nearby researchers recorded surprisingly 
high concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: 
radon and thoron. As stress builds up in the crust right 
before an earthquake, microfractures allow these gases 
to escape to the surface. These scientists think that if we built 
a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas, it could become a promising 
warning system– potentially predicting quakes 
a week in advance. Of course, none of these technologies 
would be as helpful as simply looking deep inside 
the earth itself. With a deeper view we might be able to track and predict large-scale 
geological changes in real time, possibly saving tens of thousands 
of lives a year. But for now, these technologies can help us prepare 
and respond quickly to areas in need– without waiting for directions 
from a vase.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What method was first used to predict earthquakes?
Options: A. Potassium–Argon (40K–39Ar), B. Radon–Thoron (222Rn–220Rn), C. Zhang Heng’s seismoscope, D. NASA’s Quakesim software
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the invention presented by Chinese polymath Zhang Heng to the Han court in 132 CE? Options: A. A device to predict the weather, B. A large vase that could tell them whenever an earthquake occurred in their kingdom, C. A tool to measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle, D. A system to track the movement of tectonic plates Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, why are earthquakes hard to anticipate? Options: A. Because they occur randomly, B. Due to the many variables involved, including the movement of tectonic plates, different rocks, friction, and high temperatures, C. Because they only occur in specific regions, D. Because they are caused by a single factor Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary reason for the movement of tectonic plates? Options: A. The interaction of different rocks, B. The movement of hot, partially molten rock in the Earth's mantle, C. The gravitational forces acting on the plates, D. The currents of hot rocks moving throughout the Earth's mantle Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do some rocks react differently to friction and high temperatures? Options: A. They become stronger, B. They become weaker, C. Some partially melt and release lubricating fluids, while others become dry and prone to pressure build-ups, D. They remain unchanged Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is one of the most reliable clues for predicting earthquakes? Options: A. The movement of tectonic plates, B. The vibrations the Earth elicits before a quake, C. Long-term forecasting related to when and where earthquakes have previously occurred, D. The concentration of radon and thoron gases Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the purpose of NASA's Quakesim software? Options: A. To track the movement of tectonic plates, B. To predict the weather, C. To identify regions at risk of earthquakes using a rigorous blend of geological data, D. To measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: C
Question 7: What recent studies indicate might be the most telling signs of a quake? Options: A. The movement of tectonic plates, B. The vibrations the Earth elicits before a quake, C. High concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: radon and thoron, D. The interaction of different rocks Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the potential advantage of building a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas? Options: A. It could become a promising warning system, potentially predicting quakes a week in advance, B. It could track the movement of tectonic plates, C. It could predict the weather, D. It could measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: A

They are not capable of recording primary seismic waves, C. They are not reliable in earthquake-prone areas, D. They are not useful for predicting earthquakes Correct Option: A

It could help prepare and respond quickly to areas in need, B. It could save tens of thousands of lives a year, C. It could predict the weather, D. It could measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 132 CE, Chinese polymath Zhang Heng presented the Han court with 
his latest invention. This large vase, he claimed, could tell them whenever an earthquake 
occurred in their kingdom– including the direction 
they should send aid. The court was somewhat skeptical, especially when the device triggered 
on a seemingly quiet afternoon. But when messengers came 
for help days later, their doubts turned to gratitude. Today, we no longer rely on pots to 
identify seismic events, but earthquakes still offer a unique
challenge to those trying to track them. So why are earthquakes so 
hard to anticipate, and how could we get better 
at predicting them? To answer that, we need to understand some theories 
behind how earthquakes occur. Earth’s crust is made from several vast, 
jagged slabs of rock called tectonic plates, each riding on a hot, partially molten
layer of Earth’s mantle. This causes the plates to 
spread very slowly, at anywhere from 1 to 20 
centimeters per year. But these tiny movements are powerful 
enough to cause deep cracks in the
interacting plates. And in unstable zones, the intensifying pressure may 
ultimately trigger an earthquake. It’s hard enough to monitor these 
miniscule movements, but the factors that turn shifts into 
seismic events are far more varied. Different fault lines juxtapose 
different rocks– some of which are stronger–or weaker–
under pressure. Diverse rocks also react differently to
friction and high temperatures. Some partially melt, and can release
lubricating fluids made of superheated minerals that reduce fault line friction. But some are left dry, prone to dangerous build-ups of pressure. And all these faults are subject to 
varying gravitational forces, as well as the currents of hot rocks
moving throughout Earth’s mantle. So which of these hidden variables 
should we be analyzing, and how do they fit into our 
growing prediction toolkit? Because some of these forces occur 
at largely constant rates, the behavior of the plates 
is somewhat cyclical. Today, many of our most reliable clues 
come from long-term forecasting, related to when and where earthquakes 
have previously occurred. At the scale of millennia, this allows us to make predictions 
about when highly active faults, like the San Andreas, are overdue for a massive earthquake. But due to the many variables involved, this method can only predict 
very loose timeframes. To predict more imminent events, researchers have investigated the 
vibrations Earth elicits before a quake. Geologists have long used seismometers to track and map these tiny shifts
in the earth’s crust. And today, most smartphones are 
also capable of recording primary seismic waves. With a network of phones around the globe, scientists could potentially 
crowdsource a rich, detailed warning system that alerts 
people to incoming quakes. Unfortunately, phones might not be able
to provide the advance notice needed to enact safety protocols. But such detailed readings 
would still be useful for prediction tools like NASA’s 
Quakesim software, which can use a rigorous blend of 
geological data to identify regions at risk. However, recent studies indicate the most telling signs of a quake might be
invisible to all these sensors. In 2011, just before an earthquake struck 
the east coast of Japan, nearby researchers recorded surprisingly 
high concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: 
radon and thoron. As stress builds up in the crust right 
before an earthquake, microfractures allow these gases 
to escape to the surface. These scientists think that if we built 
a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas, it could become a promising 
warning system– potentially predicting quakes 
a week in advance. Of course, none of these technologies 
would be as helpful as simply looking deep inside 
the earth itself. With a deeper view we might be able to track and predict large-scale 
geological changes in real time, possibly saving tens of thousands 
of lives a year. But for now, these technologies can help us prepare 
and respond quickly to areas in need– without waiting for directions 
from a vase.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of the instrument used to record seismic waves generated by earthquakes?
Options: A. A seismoscope, B. A seismogram, C. A seismometer, D. A seismologist
Correct Option: C

A system to track the movement of tectonic plates Correct Option: B

Question 5: What is one of the most reliable clues for predicting earthquakes? Options: A. The movement of tectonic plates, B. The vibrations the Earth elicits before a quake, C. Long-term forecasting related to when and where earthquakes have previously occurred, D. The concentration of radon and thoron gases Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the purpose of NASA's Quakesim software? Options: A. To track the movement of tectonic plates, B. To predict the weather, C. To identify regions at risk of earthquakes using a rigorous blend of geological data, D. To measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: C
Question 7: What recent studies indicate might be the most telling signs of a quake? Options: A. The movement of tectonic plates, B. The vibrations the Earth elicits before a quake, C. High concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: radon and thoron, D. The interaction of different rocks Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the potential advantage of building a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas? Options: A. It could become a promising warning system, potentially predicting quakes a week in advance, B. It could track the movement of tectonic plates, C. It could predict the weather, D. It could measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is one of the limitations of using smartphones to record primary seismic waves? Options: A. They might not be able to provide the advance notice needed to enact safety protocols, B. They are not capable of recording primary seismic waves, C. They are not reliable in earthquake-prone areas, D. They are not useful for predicting earthquakes Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is one of the potential benefits of being able to track and predict large-scale geological changes in real time? Options: A. It could help prepare and respond quickly to areas in need, B. It could save tens of thousands of lives a year, C. It could predict the weather, D. It could measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although Question 6 does not directly ask about the instrument used to record seismic waves, it does mention NASA's Quakesim software, which uses geological data, including data from seismometers.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 132 CE, Chinese polymath Zhang Heng presented the Han court with 
his latest invention. This large vase, he claimed, could tell them whenever an earthquake 
occurred in their kingdom– including the direction 
they should send aid. The court was somewhat skeptical, especially when the device triggered 
on a seemingly quiet afternoon. But when messengers came 
for help days later, their doubts turned to gratitude. Today, we no longer rely on pots to 
identify seismic events, but earthquakes still offer a unique
challenge to those trying to track them. So why are earthquakes so 
hard to anticipate, and how could we get better 
at predicting them? To answer that, we need to understand some theories 
behind how earthquakes occur. Earth’s crust is made from several vast, 
jagged slabs of rock called tectonic plates, each riding on a hot, partially molten
layer of Earth’s mantle. This causes the plates to 
spread very slowly, at anywhere from 1 to 20 
centimeters per year. But these tiny movements are powerful 
enough to cause deep cracks in the
interacting plates. And in unstable zones, the intensifying pressure may 
ultimately trigger an earthquake. It’s hard enough to monitor these 
miniscule movements, but the factors that turn shifts into 
seismic events are far more varied. Different fault lines juxtapose 
different rocks– some of which are stronger–or weaker–
under pressure. Diverse rocks also react differently to
friction and high temperatures. Some partially melt, and can release
lubricating fluids made of superheated minerals that reduce fault line friction. But some are left dry, prone to dangerous build-ups of pressure. And all these faults are subject to 
varying gravitational forces, as well as the currents of hot rocks
moving throughout Earth’s mantle. So which of these hidden variables 
should we be analyzing, and how do they fit into our 
growing prediction toolkit? Because some of these forces occur 
at largely constant rates, the behavior of the plates 
is somewhat cyclical. Today, many of our most reliable clues 
come from long-term forecasting, related to when and where earthquakes 
have previously occurred. At the scale of millennia, this allows us to make predictions 
about when highly active faults, like the San Andreas, are overdue for a massive earthquake. But due to the many variables involved, this method can only predict 
very loose timeframes. To predict more imminent events, researchers have investigated the 
vibrations Earth elicits before a quake. Geologists have long used seismometers to track and map these tiny shifts
in the earth’s crust. And today, most smartphones are 
also capable of recording primary seismic waves. With a network of phones around the globe, scientists could potentially 
crowdsource a rich, detailed warning system that alerts 
people to incoming quakes. Unfortunately, phones might not be able
to provide the advance notice needed to enact safety protocols. But such detailed readings 
would still be useful for prediction tools like NASA’s 
Quakesim software, which can use a rigorous blend of 
geological data to identify regions at risk. However, recent studies indicate the most telling signs of a quake might be
invisible to all these sensors. In 2011, just before an earthquake struck 
the east coast of Japan, nearby researchers recorded surprisingly 
high concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: 
radon and thoron. As stress builds up in the crust right 
before an earthquake, microfractures allow these gases 
to escape to the surface. These scientists think that if we built 
a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas, it could become a promising 
warning system– potentially predicting quakes 
a week in advance. Of course, none of these technologies 
would be as helpful as simply looking deep inside 
the earth itself. With a deeper view we might be able to track and predict large-scale 
geological changes in real time, possibly saving tens of thousands 
of lives a year. But for now, these technologies can help us prepare 
and respond quickly to areas in need– without waiting for directions 
from a vase.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How fast do tectonic plates move?
Options: A. As quickly as human nails grow, B. 1–20 meters per year, C. 1–20 centimeters per day, D. 1–20 micrometers per year
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
In 132 CE, Chinese polymath Zhang Heng presented the Han court with 
his latest invention. This large vase, he claimed, could tell them whenever an earthquake 
occurred in their kingdom– including the direction 
they should send aid. The court was somewhat skeptical, especially when the device triggered 
on a seemingly quiet afternoon. But when messengers came 
for help days later, their doubts turned to gratitude. Today, we no longer rely on pots to 
identify seismic events, but earthquakes still offer a unique
challenge to those trying to track them. So why are earthquakes so 
hard to anticipate, and how could we get better 
at predicting them? To answer that, we need to understand some theories 
behind how earthquakes occur. Earth’s crust is made from several vast, 
jagged slabs of rock called tectonic plates, each riding on a hot, partially molten
layer of Earth’s mantle. This causes the plates to 
spread very slowly, at anywhere from 1 to 20 
centimeters per year. But these tiny movements are powerful 
enough to cause deep cracks in the
interacting plates. And in unstable zones, the intensifying pressure may 
ultimately trigger an earthquake. It’s hard enough to monitor these 
miniscule movements, but the factors that turn shifts into 
seismic events are far more varied. Different fault lines juxtapose 
different rocks– some of which are stronger–or weaker–
under pressure. Diverse rocks also react differently to
friction and high temperatures. Some partially melt, and can release
lubricating fluids made of superheated minerals that reduce fault line friction. But some are left dry, prone to dangerous build-ups of pressure. And all these faults are subject to 
varying gravitational forces, as well as the currents of hot rocks
moving throughout Earth’s mantle. So which of these hidden variables 
should we be analyzing, and how do they fit into our 
growing prediction toolkit? Because some of these forces occur 
at largely constant rates, the behavior of the plates 
is somewhat cyclical. Today, many of our most reliable clues 
come from long-term forecasting, related to when and where earthquakes 
have previously occurred. At the scale of millennia, this allows us to make predictions 
about when highly active faults, like the San Andreas, are overdue for a massive earthquake. But due to the many variables involved, this method can only predict 
very loose timeframes. To predict more imminent events, researchers have investigated the 
vibrations Earth elicits before a quake. Geologists have long used seismometers to track and map these tiny shifts
in the earth’s crust. And today, most smartphones are 
also capable of recording primary seismic waves. With a network of phones around the globe, scientists could potentially 
crowdsource a rich, detailed warning system that alerts 
people to incoming quakes. Unfortunately, phones might not be able
to provide the advance notice needed to enact safety protocols. But such detailed readings 
would still be useful for prediction tools like NASA’s 
Quakesim software, which can use a rigorous blend of 
geological data to identify regions at risk. However, recent studies indicate the most telling signs of a quake might be
invisible to all these sensors. In 2011, just before an earthquake struck 
the east coast of Japan, nearby researchers recorded surprisingly 
high concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: 
radon and thoron. As stress builds up in the crust right 
before an earthquake, microfractures allow these gases 
to escape to the surface. These scientists think that if we built 
a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas, it could become a promising 
warning system– potentially predicting quakes 
a week in advance. Of course, none of these technologies 
would be as helpful as simply looking deep inside 
the earth itself. With a deeper view we might be able to track and predict large-scale 
geological changes in real time, possibly saving tens of thousands 
of lives a year. But for now, these technologies can help us prepare 
and respond quickly to areas in need– without waiting for directions 
from a vase.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which method is now considered the most promising for earthquake prediction?
Options: A. Potassium–Argon (40K–39Ar), B. Radon–Thoron (222Rn–220Rn), C. Zhang Heng’s seismoscope, D. NASA’s Quakesim software
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5

**Transcript**:
In 132 CE, Chinese polymath Zhang Heng presented the Han court with 
his latest invention. This large vase, he claimed, could tell them whenever an earthquake 
occurred in their kingdom– including the direction 
they should send aid. The court was somewhat skeptical, especially when the device triggered 
on a seemingly quiet afternoon. But when messengers came 
for help days later, their doubts turned to gratitude. Today, we no longer rely on pots to 
identify seismic events, but earthquakes still offer a unique
challenge to those trying to track them. So why are earthquakes so 
hard to anticipate, and how could we get better 
at predicting them? To answer that, we need to understand some theories 
behind how earthquakes occur. Earth’s crust is made from several vast, 
jagged slabs of rock called tectonic plates, each riding on a hot, partially molten
layer of Earth’s mantle. This causes the plates to 
spread very slowly, at anywhere from 1 to 20 
centimeters per year. But these tiny movements are powerful 
enough to cause deep cracks in the
interacting plates. And in unstable zones, the intensifying pressure may 
ultimately trigger an earthquake. It’s hard enough to monitor these 
miniscule movements, but the factors that turn shifts into 
seismic events are far more varied. Different fault lines juxtapose 
different rocks– some of which are stronger–or weaker–
under pressure. Diverse rocks also react differently to
friction and high temperatures. Some partially melt, and can release
lubricating fluids made of superheated minerals that reduce fault line friction. But some are left dry, prone to dangerous build-ups of pressure. And all these faults are subject to 
varying gravitational forces, as well as the currents of hot rocks
moving throughout Earth’s mantle. So which of these hidden variables 
should we be analyzing, and how do they fit into our 
growing prediction toolkit? Because some of these forces occur 
at largely constant rates, the behavior of the plates 
is somewhat cyclical. Today, many of our most reliable clues 
come from long-term forecasting, related to when and where earthquakes 
have previously occurred. At the scale of millennia, this allows us to make predictions 
about when highly active faults, like the San Andreas, are overdue for a massive earthquake. But due to the many variables involved, this method can only predict 
very loose timeframes. To predict more imminent events, researchers have investigated the 
vibrations Earth elicits before a quake. Geologists have long used seismometers to track and map these tiny shifts
in the earth’s crust. And today, most smartphones are 
also capable of recording primary seismic waves. With a network of phones around the globe, scientists could potentially 
crowdsource a rich, detailed warning system that alerts 
people to incoming quakes. Unfortunately, phones might not be able
to provide the advance notice needed to enact safety protocols. But such detailed readings 
would still be useful for prediction tools like NASA’s 
Quakesim software, which can use a rigorous blend of 
geological data to identify regions at risk. However, recent studies indicate the most telling signs of a quake might be
invisible to all these sensors. In 2011, just before an earthquake struck 
the east coast of Japan, nearby researchers recorded surprisingly 
high concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: 
radon and thoron. As stress builds up in the crust right 
before an earthquake, microfractures allow these gases 
to escape to the surface. These scientists think that if we built 
a vast network of radon-thoron detectors in earthquake-prone areas, it could become a promising 
warning system– potentially predicting quakes 
a week in advance. Of course, none of these technologies 
would be as helpful as simply looking deep inside 
the earth itself. With a deeper view we might be able to track and predict large-scale 
geological changes in real time, possibly saving tens of thousands 
of lives a year. But for now, these technologies can help us prepare 
and respond quickly to areas in need– without waiting for directions 
from a vase.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long in advance could the Radon–Thoron method predict earthquakes?
Options: A. 7 minutes, B. 7 hours, C. 7 days, D. 7 weeks
Correct Option: C

A large vase that could tell them whenever an earthquake occurred in their kingdom, C. A tool to measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle, D. A system to track the movement of tectonic plates Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, why are earthquakes hard to anticipate? Options: A. Because they occur randomly, B. Due to the many variables involved, including the movement of tectonic plates, different rocks, friction, and high temperatures, C. Because they only occur in specific regions, D. Because they are caused by a single factor Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary reason for the movement of tectonic plates? Options: A. The interaction of different rocks, B. The movement of hot, partially molten rock in the Earth's mantle, C. The gravitational forces acting on the plates, D. The currents of hot rocks moving throughout the Earth's mantle Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do some rocks react differently to friction and high temperatures? Options: A. They become stronger, B. They become weaker, C. Some partially melt and release lubricating fluids, while others become dry and prone to pressure build-ups, D. They remain unchanged Correct Option: C

Long-term forecasting related to when and where earthquakes have previously occurred, D. The concentration of radon and thoron gases Correct Option: C

To identify regions at risk of earthquakes using a rigorous blend of geological data, D. To measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: C

High concentrations of the radioactive isotope pair: radon and thoron, D. The interaction of different rocks Correct Option: C

It could become a promising warning system, potentially predicting quakes a week in advance, B. It could track the movement of tectonic plates, C. It could predict the weather, D. It could measure the temperature of the Earth's mantle Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In January of 1953, a tidal surge 
shook the North Sea. The titanic waves flooded 
the Dutch coastline, killing almost 2,000 people. 54 years later, a similar storm 
threatened the region. But this time, the Netherlands 
were ready. As the water swelled, state-of-the-art computer sensors 
activated emergency protocols. Over the next 30 minutes, a pair of 240-meter steel arms 
swung shut, protecting the channel ahead. Using 680-tonne ball joints, the barrier moved in rhythm 
with the shifting wind and waves. By morning, the storm had passed 
with minimal flooding. The first field activation 
of the Maeslantkering had been a resounding success. As one of the planet’s largest mobile 
structures, this storm surge barrier 
is a marvel of human engineering. But the Maeslantkering is just one part
of a massive, interlocking system of water controls 
known as the Delta Works— the most sophisticated flood prevention 
project in the world. The Netherlands has a long history 
with water management. The country lies along the delta 
of three major European rivers, and nearly a quarter of its territory 
is below sea level. This geography makes the region 
extremely prone to flooding. So much so, that some of the earliest 
Dutch governing bodies were informal “water boards” that 
coordinated flood protection projects. But after the storms of 1953, the Dutch
government took more official measures. They established the Delta Commission, and tasked them with protecting 
the entire southwestern region. Focusing on densely populated cities, their aim was to reduce the annual odds 
of flooding below 1 in 10,000— about 100 times as safe
as the average coastal city. Accomplishing this lofty goal required
various infrastructure projects along the southwestern coast. The first line of defense was to dam 
the region’s flood-prone estuaries. These large inlets fed many of 
the country’s rivers into the North Sea, and during storms they allowed 
flood water to surge inland. Using a series of dams, the Delta 
Commission transformed these estuaries into expansive lakes that serve 
as nature preserves and community parks. However, this solution wouldn’t work 
for the Nieuwe Waterweg. As the lifeblood of the local shipping 
industry, this passage had to be kept open 
in safe conditions, and barricaded during storm surges. In 1998, the completed Maeslantkering provided the flexible 
protection necessary. Alongside additional barriers, 
like grassy dikes and concrete seawalls, these fortifications made up the bulk 
of the Delta Works project, which was primarily focused on 
holding back ocean storms. But in the following decades, 
the Dutch pursued additional plans to complement the Delta Works 
and protect against floods further inland. Under the "Room for the River" plan, farms and dikes were relocated 
away from the shore. This left more space for water 
to collect in low-lying floodplains, creating reservoirs and habitats 
for local wildlife. This strategic retreat not only 
decreased flood risk, but allowed for the redeveloped 
settlements to be built more densely and sustainably. Perhaps no city embodies the Netherlands' 
multi-pronged approach to water management as much as Rotterdam, a thriving city 
almost entirely below sea level. When a storm threatens, densely populated older districts 
are protected by traditional dikes. Meanwhile, newer districts 
have been artificially elevated, often sporting green roofs 
that store rainwater. Numerous structures around the city 
transform into water storage facilities, including parking garages and plazas which normally serve as theaters 
and sports arenas. Meanwhile in the harbor, floating 
pavilions rise with the water level. These are the first of several planned 
amphibious structures, some of which house water purification
systems and solar collectors. These strategies are just some 
of the technologies and policies that have put the Netherlands 
at the cutting edge of water management. The country continues to find new ways 
to make cities more resilient to natural disasters. And as the rising sea levels 
caused by climate change threaten low-lying cities 
across the world, the Netherlands offers an exceptional 
example of how to go with the flow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long are each of the two steel arms of the Maeslantkering?
Options: A. 50 meter, B. 120 meter, C. 240 meter, D. 400 meter
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What significant event led to the Netherlands taking official measures for flood protection? Options: A. A series of storms in the early 20th century, B. The establishment of the Delta Commission, C. The completion of the Maeslantkering, D. The flooding of the Nieuwe Waterweg Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary goal of the Delta Works project? Options: A. To protect the entire southwestern region from flooding, B. To reduce the annual odds of flooding below 1 in 10,000, C. To create nature preserves and community parks, D. To promote sustainable development Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the Dutch government initially manage flood protection projects? Options: A. Through a centralized authority, B. Through a series of dams in the estuaries, C. Through informal "water boards", D. Through a combination of traditional dikes and concrete seawalls Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the "Room for the River" plan? Options: A. To increase the height of traditional dikes, B. To relocate farms and dikes away from the shore, C. To create more space for water to collect in low-lying floodplains, D. To promote sustainable development in urban areas Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the impact of the "Room for the River" plan on flood risk and urban development? Options: A. It increased flood risk and reduced urban density, B. It decreased flood risk and allowed for redeveloped settlements to be built more densely and sustainably, C. It had no impact on flood risk or urban development, D. It increased urban density but had no impact on flood risk Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the significance of the Netherlands' approach to water management in the context of climate change? Options: A. It is a unique solution that cannot be replicated elsewhere, B. It is a temporary solution that will be obsolete in the near future, C. It offers an exceptional example of how to make cities more resilient to natural disasters, D. It is a costly solution that is not feasible for other countries Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the purpose of the Maeslantkering? Options: A. To protect the Nieuwe Waterweg from flooding, B. To create a nature preserve and community park, C. To serve as a flexible protection barrier during storm surges, D. To promote sustainable development in urban areas Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the Maeslantkering work? Options: A. It uses a series of dams to block the flow of water, B. It uses 680-tonne ball joints to swing shut and protect the channel, C. It uses traditional dikes to prevent flooding, D. It uses a combination of concrete seawalls and grassy dikes Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the Maeslantkering in the context of the Delta Works project? Options: A. It is a small component of the project that has little impact, B. It is a crucial component of the project that provides flexible protection, C. It is a temporary solution that will be replaced in the near future, D. It is a costly solution that is not feasible for other countries Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the key to the Netherlands' approach to water management? Options: A. A focus on technological innovation, B. A reliance on traditional dikes and seawalls, C. A combination of technological innovation and adaptive planning, D. A focus on reducing water levels in the Netherlands Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the length of the steel arms of the Maeslantkering, while the generated MCQs do not have a direct match for this question. However, Question 7 and Question 8 are related to the Maeslantkering, but they do not ask about the length of the steel arms.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 8, which asks about how the Maeslantkering works. This question mentions the use of 680-tonne ball joints, which is mentioned in the transcript as a feature of the Maeslantkering. However, this question does not ask about the length of the steel arms.

Therefore, I would say that there is no direct match for the ground truth MCQ among the generated MCQs, but Question 8 is the closest related question.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8 (Note: This is not a direct match, but rather a related question)

**Transcript**:
In January of 1953, a tidal surge 
shook the North Sea. The titanic waves flooded 
the Dutch coastline, killing almost 2,000 people. 54 years later, a similar storm 
threatened the region. But this time, the Netherlands 
were ready. As the water swelled, state-of-the-art computer sensors 
activated emergency protocols. Over the next 30 minutes, a pair of 240-meter steel arms 
swung shut, protecting the channel ahead. Using 680-tonne ball joints, the barrier moved in rhythm 
with the shifting wind and waves. By morning, the storm had passed 
with minimal flooding. The first field activation 
of the Maeslantkering had been a resounding success. As one of the planet’s largest mobile 
structures, this storm surge barrier 
is a marvel of human engineering. But the Maeslantkering is just one part
of a massive, interlocking system of water controls 
known as the Delta Works— the most sophisticated flood prevention 
project in the world. The Netherlands has a long history 
with water management. The country lies along the delta 
of three major European rivers, and nearly a quarter of its territory 
is below sea level. This geography makes the region 
extremely prone to flooding. So much so, that some of the earliest 
Dutch governing bodies were informal “water boards” that 
coordinated flood protection projects. But after the storms of 1953, the Dutch
government took more official measures. They established the Delta Commission, and tasked them with protecting 
the entire southwestern region. Focusing on densely populated cities, their aim was to reduce the annual odds 
of flooding below 1 in 10,000— about 100 times as safe
as the average coastal city. Accomplishing this lofty goal required
various infrastructure projects along the southwestern coast. The first line of defense was to dam 
the region’s flood-prone estuaries. These large inlets fed many of 
the country’s rivers into the North Sea, and during storms they allowed 
flood water to surge inland. Using a series of dams, the Delta 
Commission transformed these estuaries into expansive lakes that serve 
as nature preserves and community parks. However, this solution wouldn’t work 
for the Nieuwe Waterweg. As the lifeblood of the local shipping 
industry, this passage had to be kept open 
in safe conditions, and barricaded during storm surges. In 1998, the completed Maeslantkering provided the flexible 
protection necessary. Alongside additional barriers, 
like grassy dikes and concrete seawalls, these fortifications made up the bulk 
of the Delta Works project, which was primarily focused on 
holding back ocean storms. But in the following decades, 
the Dutch pursued additional plans to complement the Delta Works 
and protect against floods further inland. Under the "Room for the River" plan, farms and dikes were relocated 
away from the shore. This left more space for water 
to collect in low-lying floodplains, creating reservoirs and habitats 
for local wildlife. This strategic retreat not only 
decreased flood risk, but allowed for the redeveloped 
settlements to be built more densely and sustainably. Perhaps no city embodies the Netherlands' 
multi-pronged approach to water management as much as Rotterdam, a thriving city 
almost entirely below sea level. When a storm threatens, densely populated older districts 
are protected by traditional dikes. Meanwhile, newer districts 
have been artificially elevated, often sporting green roofs 
that store rainwater. Numerous structures around the city 
transform into water storage facilities, including parking garages and plazas which normally serve as theaters 
and sports arenas. Meanwhile in the harbor, floating 
pavilions rise with the water level. These are the first of several planned 
amphibious structures, some of which house water purification
systems and solar collectors. These strategies are just some 
of the technologies and policies that have put the Netherlands 
at the cutting edge of water management. The country continues to find new ways 
to make cities more resilient to natural disasters. And as the rising sea levels 
caused by climate change threaten low-lying cities 
across the world, the Netherlands offers an exceptional 
example of how to go with the flow.

various infrastructure projects along the southwestern coast. The first line of defense was to dam 
the region’s flood-prone estuaries. These large inlets fed many of 
the country’s rivers into the North Sea, and during storms they allowed 
flood water to surge inland. Using a series of dams, the Delta 
Commission transformed these estuaries into expansive lakes that serve 
as nature preserves and community parks. However, this solution wouldn’t work 
for the Nieuwe Waterweg. As the lifeblood of the local shipping 
industry, this passage had to be kept open 
in safe conditions, and barricaded during storm surges. In 1998, the completed Maeslantkering provided the flexible 
protection necessary. Alongside additional barriers, 
like grassy dikes and concrete seawalls, these fortifications made up the bulk 
of the Delta Works project, which was primarily focused on 
holding back ocean storms. But in the following decades, 
the Dutch pursued additional plans to complement the Delta Works 
and protect against floods further inland. Under the "Room for the River" plan, farms and dikes were relocated 
away from the shore. This left more space for water 
to collect in low-lying floodplains, creating reservoirs and habitats 
for local wildlife. This strategic retreat not only 
decreased flood risk, but allowed for the redeveloped 
settlements to be built more densely and sustainably. Perhaps no city embodies the Netherlands' 
multi-pronged approach to water management as much as Rotterdam, a thriving city 
almost entirely below sea level. When a storm threatens, densely populated older districts 
are protected by traditional dikes. Meanwhile, newer districts 
have been artificially elevated, often sporting green roofs 
that store rainwater. Numerous structures around the city 
transform into water storage facilities, including parking garages and plazas which normally serve as theaters 
and sports arenas. Meanwhile in the harbor, floating 
pavilions rise with the water level. These are the first of several planned 
amphibious structures, some of which house water purification
systems and solar collectors. These strategies are just some 
of the technologies and policies that have put the Netherlands 
at the cutting edge of water management. The country continues to find new ways 
to make cities more resilient to natural disasters. And as the rising sea levels 
caused by climate change threaten low-lying cities 
across the world, the Netherlands offers an exceptional 
example of how to go with the flow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how much of the Netherlands’ territory lies below sea level?
Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 25%, D. 75%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What significant event led to the Netherlands taking official measures for flood protection? Options: A. A series of storms in the early 20th century, B. The establishment of the Delta Commission, C. The completion of the Maeslantkering, D. The flooding of the Nieuwe Waterweg Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary goal of the Delta Works project? Options: A. To protect the entire southwestern region from flooding, B. To reduce the annual odds of flooding below 1 in 10,000, C. To create nature preserves and community parks, D. To promote sustainable development Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the Dutch government initially manage flood protection projects? Options: A. Through a centralized authority, B. Through a series of dams in the estuaries, C. Through informal "water boards", D. Through a combination of traditional dikes and concrete seawalls Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the "Room for the River" plan? Options: A. To increase the height of traditional dikes, B. To relocate farms and dikes away from the shore, C. To create more space for water to collect in low-lying floodplains, D. To promote sustainable development in urban areas Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the impact of the "Room for the River" plan on flood risk and urban development? Options: A. It increased flood risk and reduced urban density, B. It decreased flood risk and allowed for redeveloped settlements to be built more densely and sustainably, C. It had no impact on flood risk or urban development, D. It increased urban density but had no impact on flood risk Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the significance of the Netherlands' approach to water management in the context of climate change? Options: A. It is a unique solution that cannot be replicated elsewhere, B. It is a temporary solution that will be obsolete in the near future, C. It offers an exceptional example of how to make cities more resilient to natural disasters, D. It is a costly solution that is not feasible for other countries Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the purpose of the Maeslantkering? Options: A. To protect the Nieuwe Waterweg from flooding, B. To create a nature preserve and community park, C. To serve as a flexible protection barrier during storm surges, D. To promote sustainable development in urban areas Correct Option: C
Question 8: How does the Maeslantkering work? Options: A. It uses a series of dams to block the flow of water, B. It uses 680-tonne ball joints to swing shut and protect the channel, C. It uses traditional dikes to prevent flooding, D. It uses a combination of concrete seawalls and grassy dikes Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the Maeslantkering in the context of the Delta Works project? Options: A. It is a small component of the project that has little impact, B. It is a crucial component of the project that provides flexible protection, C. It is a temporary solution that will be replaced in the near future, D. It is a costly solution that is not feasible for other countries Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the key to the Netherlands' approach to water management? Options: A. A focus on technological innovation, B. A reliance on traditional dikes and seawalls, C. A combination of technological innovation and adaptive planning, D. A focus on reducing water levels in the Netherlands Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In January of 1953, a tidal surge 
shook the North Sea. The titanic waves flooded 
the Dutch coastline, killing almost 2,000 people. 54 years later, a similar storm 
threatened the region. But this time, the Netherlands 
were ready. As the water swelled, state-of-the-art computer sensors 
activated emergency protocols. Over the next 30 minutes, a pair of 240-meter steel arms 
swung shut, protecting the channel ahead. Using 680-tonne ball joints, the barrier moved in rhythm 
with the shifting wind and waves. By morning, the storm had passed 
with minimal flooding. The first field activation 
of the Maeslantkering had been a resounding success. As one of the planet’s largest mobile 
structures, this storm surge barrier 
is a marvel of human engineering. But the Maeslantkering is just one part
of a massive, interlocking system of water controls 
known as the Delta Works— the most sophisticated flood prevention 
project in the world. The Netherlands has a long history 
with water management. The country lies along the delta 
of three major European rivers, and nearly a quarter of its territory 
is below sea level. This geography makes the region 
extremely prone to flooding. So much so, that some of the earliest 
Dutch governing bodies were informal “water boards” that 
coordinated flood protection projects. But after the storms of 1953, the Dutch
government took more official measures. They established the Delta Commission, and tasked them with protecting 
the entire southwestern region. Focusing on densely populated cities, their aim was to reduce the annual odds 
of flooding below 1 in 10,000— about 100 times as safe
as the average coastal city. Accomplishing this lofty goal required
various infrastructure projects along the southwestern coast. The first line of defense was to dam 
the region’s flood-prone estuaries. These large inlets fed many of 
the country’s rivers into the North Sea, and during storms they allowed 
flood water to surge inland. Using a series of dams, the Delta 
Commission transformed these estuaries into expansive lakes that serve 
as nature preserves and community parks. However, this solution wouldn’t work 
for the Nieuwe Waterweg. As the lifeblood of the local shipping 
industry, this passage had to be kept open 
in safe conditions, and barricaded during storm surges. In 1998, the completed Maeslantkering provided the flexible 
protection necessary. Alongside additional barriers, 
like grassy dikes and concrete seawalls, these fortifications made up the bulk 
of the Delta Works project, which was primarily focused on 
holding back ocean storms. But in the following decades, 
the Dutch pursued additional plans to complement the Delta Works 
and protect against floods further inland. Under the "Room for the River" plan, farms and dikes were relocated 
away from the shore. This left more space for water 
to collect in low-lying floodplains, creating reservoirs and habitats 
for local wildlife. This strategic retreat not only 
decreased flood risk, but allowed for the redeveloped 
settlements to be built more densely and sustainably. Perhaps no city embodies the Netherlands' 
multi-pronged approach to water management as much as Rotterdam, a thriving city 
almost entirely below sea level. When a storm threatens, densely populated older districts 
are protected by traditional dikes. Meanwhile, newer districts 
have been artificially elevated, often sporting green roofs 
that store rainwater. Numerous structures around the city 
transform into water storage facilities, including parking garages and plazas which normally serve as theaters 
and sports arenas. Meanwhile in the harbor, floating 
pavilions rise with the water level. These are the first of several planned 
amphibious structures, some of which house water purification
systems and solar collectors. These strategies are just some 
of the technologies and policies that have put the Netherlands 
at the cutting edge of water management. The country continues to find new ways 
to make cities more resilient to natural disasters. And as the rising sea levels 
caused by climate change threaten low-lying cities 
across the world, the Netherlands offers an exceptional 
example of how to go with the flow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is NOT a flood prevention measure?
Options: A. A storm surge barrier, B. A dike, C. Artificially-elevated land, D. A ball joint
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 13th Century, Genghis Khan embarked on a mission
to take over Eurasia, swiftly conquering countries and drawing 
them into his expanding Mongol Empire. With his vast armies he became almost 
unstoppable. But, legend has it that there was 
one obstacle that even the impressive Khan couldn’t 
overcome: A towering wall of ice, grown by locals across a mountain pass to stop the Khan’s armies from 
invading their territory. No one knows how historically accurate 
that particular story is, but remarkably, it draws on fact: For centuries, in the Karakoram 
and Himalayan mountain ranges, people have been growing glaciers 
and using these homemade bodies of ice as sources of drinking water and 
irrigation for their crops. But before we get to that fascinating 
phenomenon, it’s important to understand the 
difference between glaciers that grow in the wild, and those that humans create. In the wild, glaciers require three conditions to grow: Snowfall, cold temperatures, and time. First, a great deal of snow falls and 
accumulates. Cold temperatures then ensure that the 
stacked up snow persists throughout the winter, spring, 
summer, and fall. Over the following years, decades, 
and centuries, the pressure of the accumulated snow transforms layers into highly compacted 
glacial ice. Artificially growing a glacier, however, is completely different. At the confluence of three great 
mountain ranges, the Himalayas, Karakoram, and Hindu Kush, some local cultures have believed for
centuries that glaciers are alive. And what’s more, that certain glaciers can have different 
genders including male and female. Local Glacier Growers ‘breed’ new glaciers
by grafting together—or marrying— fragments of ice from male and 
female glaciers, then covering them with charcoal, 
wheat husks, cloths, or willow branches so they can reproduce. Under their protective coverings, these glacierets transform into fully 
active glaciers that grow each year with 
additional snowfall. Those then serve as lasting 
reserves of water that farmers can use 
to irrigate their crops. These practices have spread 
to other cultures, where people are creating their own 
versions of glaciers and applying them to solve serious 
modern challenges around water supplies. Take Ladakh, a high-altitude desert region
in northern India. It sits in the rain shadow of the 
Himalayas and receives on average fewer than ten 
centimeters of rain per year. As local glaciers shrink because 
of climate change, regional water scarcity is increasing. And so, local people have started growing 
their own glaciers as insurance against this uncertainty. These glaciers come in two types: 
horizontal, and vertical. Horizontal glaciers are formed when 
farmers redirect glacier meltwater into channels and pipes, then carefully siphon it off into a series
of basins made from stones and earth. Villagers minutely control the release of 
water into these reservoirs, waiting for each new layer to freeze before filling the basin 
with another wave. In early spring, these frozen pools begin to melt, supplying villagers with 
irrigation for their fields. Local people make vertical glaciers using 
the meltwater from already-existing glaciers 
high above their villages. The meltwater enters channels 
that run downhill, flowing until it reaches a crop site where it bursts forth from a pipe pointing
straight into the air. When winter temperatures dip, this water freezes as it arcs 
out of the pipe, ultimately forming a 50 meter ice 
sculpture called a stupa, shaped like an upside-down ice cream cone. This inverted form minimizes the amount
of surface area it exposes to the sun in the spring and summer. That ensures that the mini-glacier 
melts slowly and provides a reliable supply of water 
to feed the farmers’ crops. These methods may be ancient, but they’re becoming more relevant as climate change takes its 
toll on our planet. In fact, people are now growing their own
glaciers in many regions beyond Ladakh. Swiss people, utilizing modern glacier 
growing technology, created their first stupa in 2016 
in the Swiss Alps. There are plans for over 100 more in 
villages in Pakistan, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan. Perhaps one day we’ll be able to harness
our homegrown glaciers well enough to build whole walls of ice– this time not for keeping people out, but to enable life in some of the planet’s
harshest landscapes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where can you find glaciers on this planet?
Options: A. In the Arctic, B. In the Arctic and Antarctica, C. In the Arctic, Antarctica, and Asia, D. In the Arctic, Antarctica, Asia, and Africa, E. In the Arctic, Antarctica, Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas.
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the 13th-century leader who attempted to conquer Eurasia? Options: A. Genghis Khan, B. Alexander the Great, C. Napoleon Bonaparte, D. Julius Caesar Correct Option: A
Question 2: What are the three conditions required for glaciers to grow in the wild? Options: A. Snowfall, warm temperatures, and time, B. Rainfall, cold temperatures, and wind, C. Snowfall, cold temperatures, and time, D. Sunshine, dryness, and darkness Correct Option: C
Question 3: How do local Glacier Growers 'breed' new glaciers? Options: A. By grafting together fragments of ice from male and female glaciers, then covering them with charcoal, wheat husks, cloths, or willow branches, B. By melting existing glaciers and re-freezing them, C. By collecting snow from the top of mountains and transporting it to lower elevations, D. By digging holes in the ground and filling them with ice Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the purpose of creating horizontal glaciers? Options: A. To store water for irrigation during times of drought, B. To create a barrier against invading armies, C. To provide a source of drinking water for villagers, D. To store water for irrigation and provide a reliable supply of water for crops Correct Option: D
Question 5: How do local people create vertical glaciers in Ladakh? Options: A. By redirecting glacier meltwater into channels and pipes, then carefully siphoning it off into a series of basins made from stones and earth, B. By collecting snow from the top of mountains and transporting it to lower elevations, C. By digging holes in the ground and filling them with ice, D. By melting existing glaciers and re-freezing them Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the purpose of creating vertical glaciers in Ladakh? Options: A. To store water for irrigation during times of drought, B. To create a barrier against invading armies, C. To provide a source of drinking water for villagers, D. To provide a reliable supply of water to feed farmers' crops and help them adapt to climate change Correct Option: D
Question 7: Why are local people growing their own glaciers in Ladakh? Options: A. Because they are trying to reduce the impact of climate change, B. Because they are trying to increase their water supply, C. Because they are trying to create a barrier against invading armies, D. Because they are trying to cool the air and reduce temperatures Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the name of the first stupa created using modern glacier growing technology in the Swiss Alps? Options: A. The Swiss Glacier Stupa, B. The Alpine Ice Sculpture, C. The Glacier Stupa of the Swiss Alps, D. The Swiss Alps Glacier Stupa Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the potential benefit of harnessing homegrown glaciers to build whole walls of ice? Options: A. To create a barrier against invading armies, B. To provide a source of drinking water for villagers, C. To enable life in some of the planet's harshest landscapes and help people adapt to climate change, D. To cool the air and reduce temperatures Correct Option: C
Question 10: How might the methods of growing glaciers be used to address the challenges of climate change? Options: A. By creating a barrier against invading armies, B. By providing a source of drinking water for irrigation during times of drought, C. By harnessing homegrown glaciers to build whole walls of ice and enable life in some of the planet's harshest landscapes, D. By reducing the impact of climate change through sustainable water management and adaptation Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the topic of glaciers and their geographical distribution.

The generated MCQ that comes closest to the ground truth MCQ is:

Question 2: What are the three conditions required for glaciers to grow in the wild? Options: A. Snowfall, warm temperatures, and time, B. Rainfall, cold temperatures, and wind, C. Snowfall, cold temperatures, and time, D. Sunshine, dryness, and darkness Correct Option: C

However, this question does not directly address the geographical distribution of glaciers, which is the main focus of the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not available, but if I had to pick one that is somewhat related, I would say it is Question 2 (Index 2). Nevertheless, I would like to emphasize that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 13th Century, Genghis Khan embarked on a mission
to take over Eurasia, swiftly conquering countries and drawing 
them into his expanding Mongol Empire. With his vast armies he became almost 
unstoppable. But, legend has it that there was 
one obstacle that even the impressive Khan couldn’t 
overcome: A towering wall of ice, grown by locals across a mountain pass to stop the Khan’s armies from 
invading their territory. No one knows how historically accurate 
that particular story is, but remarkably, it draws on fact: For centuries, in the Karakoram 
and Himalayan mountain ranges, people have been growing glaciers 
and using these homemade bodies of ice as sources of drinking water and 
irrigation for their crops. But before we get to that fascinating 
phenomenon, it’s important to understand the 
difference between glaciers that grow in the wild, and those that humans create. In the wild, glaciers require three conditions to grow: Snowfall, cold temperatures, and time. First, a great deal of snow falls and 
accumulates. Cold temperatures then ensure that the 
stacked up snow persists throughout the winter, spring, 
summer, and fall. Over the following years, decades, 
and centuries, the pressure of the accumulated snow transforms layers into highly compacted 
glacial ice. Artificially growing a glacier, however, is completely different. At the confluence of three great 
mountain ranges, the Himalayas, Karakoram, and Hindu Kush, some local cultures have believed for
centuries that glaciers are alive. And what’s more, that certain glaciers can have different 
genders including male and female. Local Glacier Growers ‘breed’ new glaciers
by grafting together—or marrying— fragments of ice from male and 
female glaciers, then covering them with charcoal, 
wheat husks, cloths, or willow branches so they can reproduce. Under their protective coverings, these glacierets transform into fully

additional snowfall. Those then serve as lasting 
reserves of water that farmers can use 
to irrigate their crops. These practices have spread 
to other cultures, where people are creating their own

in northern India. It sits in the rain shadow of the 
Himalayas and receives on average fewer than ten 
centimeters of rain per year. As local glaciers shrink because 
of climate change, regional water scarcity is increasing. And so, local people have started growing 
their own glaciers as insurance against this uncertainty. These glaciers come in two types:

to feed the farmers’ crops. These methods may be ancient, but they’re becoming more relevant as climate change takes its 
toll on our planet. In fact, people are now growing their own

growing technology, created their first stupa in 2016 
in the Swiss Alps. There are plans for over 100 more in

our homegrown glaciers well enough to build whole walls of ice– this time not for keeping people out, but to enable life in some of the planet’s
harshest landscapes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are three basic conditions needed for glaciers to grow?
Options: A. Cold temperatures, mountains, and rain, B. Cold temperatures, time, and snow, C. Mild temperatures, high elevation, time, D. Mild temperatures, low elevation, snow
Correct Option: B

To cool the air and reduce temperatures Correct Option: C
Question 10: How might the methods of growing glaciers be used to address the challenges of climate change? Options: A. By creating a barrier against invading armies, B. By providing a source of drinking water for irrigation during times of drought, C. By harnessing homegrown glaciers to build whole walls of ice and enable life in some of the planet's harshest landscapes, D. By reducing the impact of climate change through sustainable water management and adaptation Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying the conditions required for glaciers to grow), options (providing a range of possible conditions), and content (focusing on the specific conditions necessary for glacier growth). The correct option for Question 2 (C. Snowfall, cold temperatures, and time) also matches the correct option for the ground truth MCQ (B. Cold temperatures, time, and snow), although the order of the conditions is slightly different.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 13th Century, Genghis Khan embarked on a mission
to take over Eurasia, swiftly conquering countries and drawing 
them into his expanding Mongol Empire. With his vast armies he became almost 
unstoppable. But, legend has it that there was 
one obstacle that even the impressive Khan couldn’t 
overcome: A towering wall of ice, grown by locals across a mountain pass to stop the Khan’s armies from 
invading their territory. No one knows how historically accurate 
that particular story is, but remarkably, it draws on fact: For centuries, in the Karakoram 
and Himalayan mountain ranges, people have been growing glaciers 
and using these homemade bodies of ice as sources of drinking water and 
irrigation for their crops. But before we get to that fascinating 
phenomenon, it’s important to understand the 
difference between glaciers that grow in the wild, and those that humans create. In the wild, glaciers require three conditions to grow: Snowfall, cold temperatures, and time. First, a great deal of snow falls and 
accumulates. Cold temperatures then ensure that the 
stacked up snow persists throughout the winter, spring, 
summer, and fall. Over the following years, decades, 
and centuries, the pressure of the accumulated snow transforms layers into highly compacted 
glacial ice. Artificially growing a glacier, however, is completely different. At the confluence of three great 
mountain ranges, the Himalayas, Karakoram, and Hindu Kush, some local cultures have believed for
centuries that glaciers are alive. And what’s more, that certain glaciers can have different 
genders including male and female. Local Glacier Growers ‘breed’ new glaciers
by grafting together—or marrying— fragments of ice from male and 
female glaciers, then covering them with charcoal, 
wheat husks, cloths, or willow branches so they can reproduce. Under their protective coverings, these glacierets transform into fully 
active glaciers that grow each year with 
additional snowfall. Those then serve as lasting 
reserves of water that farmers can use 
to irrigate their crops. These practices have spread 
to other cultures, where people are creating their own 
versions of glaciers and applying them to solve serious 
modern challenges around water supplies. Take Ladakh, a high-altitude desert region
in northern India. It sits in the rain shadow of the 
Himalayas and receives on average fewer than ten 
centimeters of rain per year. As local glaciers shrink because 
of climate change, regional water scarcity is increasing. And so, local people have started growing 
their own glaciers as insurance against this uncertainty. These glaciers come in two types: 
horizontal, and vertical. Horizontal glaciers are formed when 
farmers redirect glacier meltwater into channels and pipes, then carefully siphon it off into a series
of basins made from stones and earth. Villagers minutely control the release of 
water into these reservoirs, waiting for each new layer to freeze before filling the basin 
with another wave. In early spring, these frozen pools begin to melt, supplying villagers with 
irrigation for their fields. Local people make vertical glaciers using 
the meltwater from already-existing glaciers 
high above their villages. The meltwater enters channels 
that run downhill, flowing until it reaches a crop site where it bursts forth from a pipe pointing
straight into the air. When winter temperatures dip, this water freezes as it arcs 
out of the pipe, ultimately forming a 50 meter ice 
sculpture called a stupa, shaped like an upside-down ice cream cone. This inverted form minimizes the amount
of surface area it exposes to the sun in the spring and summer. That ensures that the mini-glacier 
melts slowly and provides a reliable supply of water 
to feed the farmers’ crops. These methods may be ancient, but they’re becoming more relevant as climate change takes its 
toll on our planet. In fact, people are now growing their own
glaciers in many regions beyond Ladakh. Swiss people, utilizing modern glacier 
growing technology, created their first stupa in 2016 
in the Swiss Alps. There are plans for over 100 more in 
villages in Pakistan, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan. Perhaps one day we’ll be able to harness
our homegrown glaciers well enough to build whole walls of ice– this time not for keeping people out, but to enable life in some of the planet’s
harshest landscapes.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why did people start growing their own glaciers?
Options: A. To control mountains, B. Because glaciers are beautiful, C. To provide water for their crops, D. Because glaciers are melting
Correct Option: C
